questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Partial hydatidiform mole has a 69XXY or 69XYY karyotype.

Hydatiform mole belongs to the benign group of gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD). It is an abnormality in chorionic villi making them partly proliferative and degenerative, thereby resulting in the formation of multiple small cysts. Based on the portion of the chorionic villi involved, they could be complete (diffused) or partial (focal)

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding hydatidiform moles?

choices.text: Complete moles show diffuse trophoblastic hyperplasia
Fetal tissue is seen in partial mole
Early USG is sensitive for partial moles
Complete moles have higher malignant potential

questions.solution:
Early ultrasonography is not highly sensitive in a patient with partial molar pregnancy. However, USG features like thickened, multicystic placenta along with fetal tissue or even a fetus may be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with the development of a hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency, not Vitamin C deficiency is a risk factor for hydatidiform mole.

Risk factors for hydatidiform mole are:

  • Maternal age - pregnancy in teenage and women >35 years
  • Previous history of gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Dietary deficiency - vitamin A deficiency, inadequate protein and animal fat intake
  • AB blood group.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida with bleeding PV was diagnosed to have a complete hydatidiform mole. Which of the following is not true in this condition?

choices.text: Serum β-hCG levels are highly elevated
Serum free T4 levels normalise after uterine evacuation

questions.solution:
Theca lutein cysts are rare in partial molar pregnancy, but may be seen in 25-30% of patients with complete molar pregnancy.

Serum β-hCG levels are elevated more than expected for gestational age in a complete mole.

The sensitivity of most hCG tests is set to the pregnancy hCG range. An excessive β-hCG hormone causes an oversaturation of the test assay giving a false negative UPT. This is called the hook effect.

The thyrotropin-like effects of hCG frequently cause serum free-T4 levels to be elevated which normalize after uterine evacuation.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents with spotting PV, hyperemesis, and lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. USG done is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and USG showing snowstorm appearance is suggestive of a complete mole. 

The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces. Fetus and amniotic sac are absent. 

Investigations for molar pregnancy are:

  • USG - shows snowstorm appearance
  • Serum β hCG - elevated to >2 MoM (multiples of median) for corresponding gestational age
  • Histological examination of products of conception

Snowstorms in radiology:

  • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
  • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
  • Carcinoma thyroid - pulmonary metastases (chest X-ray).

questions.text: A primigravida at 12 weeks of gestation presented with complaints of the expulsion of grape-like vesicles PV for the past day. A diagnosis of molar pregnancy was made on USG examination. Incidentally, the following adnexal lesion was also noted. What is the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given USG image shows theca lutein cysts in the ovary. These cysts are usually seen in patients with complete molar pregnancies. They are usually bilateral and are also seen in multiple pregnancies.

Theca lutein cysts result from the overstimulation of lutein elements by massive amounts of β hCG. The cystic fluid is rich in chorionic gonadotropin, estrogen, and progesterone.

questions.text: A patient who was treated for molar pregnancy came for follow-up after 4 months. Her USG revealed a large, twisted theca lutein cyst. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Untwisting of the cyst is the only management in an asymptomatic patient with a twisted theca lutein cyst.

Laparoscopic oophorectomy is done only when there is associated extensive necrosis or hemorrhage.

Theca-lutein cysts regress within 2 months after pregnancy evacuation, and hence expectant management is preferred in uncomplicated cases. If the cysts are symptomatic, they can be aspirated trans-abdominally under ultrasound guidance.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 14 weeks of gestation complains of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal bleeding for 2 weeks. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks and fetal heart sounds are absent. USG shows a snowstorm appearance and no fetus. What is the best step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy which is managed by suction and evacuation, regardless of uterine size.

If the cervix is unfavorable, slow dilatation is done with vaginal PGE1. Volume resuscitation with IV fluids and parenteral antibiotics can be given as supportive therapy. Blood transfusion is done if the patient is anaemic.

Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Women who have completed their family
  • Age >40 years
  • Uncontrolled hemorrhage
  • Perforation during surgical evacuation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman underwent suction evacuation for a hydatidiform mole. Which of the following statements is true regarding her follow-up with β-hCG estimation?

choices.text: Twice weekly estimation for a month following evacuation
Monthly follow-up for 6 months after three consecutive normal values
After 6 months of follow-up, regular yearly estimation should be done

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is followed up with serum β hCG every month for 6 months.

Follow-up after the termination of molar pregnancy is done with serum β hCG levels. During the follow-up period, pregnancy must be avoided as it might interfere with the β hCG levels.

The initial β-hCG level is obtained within 48 hours after evacuation and used as a baseline. 

It is measured weekly till it becomes negative, and three consecutive normal values are obtained. This normally happens in 4-8 weeks. 

After this, β hCG levels are measured monthly for 6 months. Women who undergo chemotherapy must be followed up for 1 year.

questions.text:
Which of the following are complications that can be seen in a patient with molar pregnancy?
  1. Pre-eclampsia
  2. Hypothyroidism
  3. Breathlessness
  4. Electrolyte imbalance
  5. Uterine perforation
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxicosis is seen as a complication of molar pregnancy, not hypothyroidism.

Complications in molar pregnancy include:

  • Immediate:
    • Early-onset pre-eclampsia - molar placentas produce more antiangiogenic proteins than normal placentas.
    • Thyrotoxicosis - as α component of hCG mimics TSH and causes thyroid storm
    • Acute pulmonary insufficiency - due to embolization of trophoblastic cells
    • Electrolyte imbalance i.e., hypokalemia, hyponatremia - due to hyperemesis caused by β hCG
    • Shock - hemorrhage due to the separation of vesicles and intra-peritoneal haemorrhage
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Late: Choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include
questions.solution:
A partial mole is not a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm (GTN).

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is the term used to describe a group of tumors due to abnormal trophoblast proliferation. Malignant forms of GTD are termed gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

Modified WHO Classification of GTD

Molar Pregnancies Trophoblastic tumors

Hydatidiform mole (benign) -Partial and Complete
Invasive mole (malignant)

Choriocarcinoma (malignant)
Placental site trophoblastic tumor (malignant)

Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (malignant)

questions.text: All of the following are non-molar trophoblastic neoplasms except _____.
questions.solution: Invasive mole is a molar trophoblastic neoplasm.

questions.text: What is the most common non-metastatic gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that develops following hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Chorioadenoma destruens or invasive mole is the most common non-metastatic GTN that follows hydatidiform moles. Almost all invasive moles arise from partial or complete moles.

Invasive mole is characterized by extensive tissue invasion by trophoblast and whole villi. They can penetrate deep into the myometrium, peritoneum, parametrium, or vaginal vault. They are locally aggressive and do not usually metastasize. 

The most common GTN following term pregnancy or miscarriage is choriocarcinoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors for malignant change in a patient with molar pregnancy?
  1. Maternal age >40 years
  2. β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  3. Theca-lutein cysts < 6 cm
  4. Uterine size that is small for gestational age
  5. Grand multiparity
questions.solution:
Maternal age >40 years, β-hCG levels >100,000 mIU/mL and grand multiparity are risk factors for malignant change in a patient with molar pregnancy.

Risk factors for malignant change are:

  • Patient's age ≥ 40 years or <20 years
  • Parity ≥3
  • Uterine size >20 weeks
  • Previous history of molar pregnancy
  • Complete moles have 15-20% risk of malignant transformation, partial moles have 1-5% risk
  • Serum β hCG >1,00,000 mIU/mL
  • Large theca lutein cysts >6 cm in diameter

Post-evacuation uterine sonographic surveillance can be used as a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. Findings indicative of malignant transformation are:

  • Suburethral nodules
  • Myometrial nodules
  • Hypervascularity.

questions.text: All of the following can be indicators of choriocarcinoma except:

choices.text: Increased number of theca lutein cysts

questions.solution:
Increased number of theca lutein cysts is not an indicator of choriocarcinoma. Increased size or persistence of theca lutein cysts indicates choriocarcinoma.

Plateau of high serum β-hCG level for four measurements for ≥3 weeks is an indicator of choriocarcinoma.

Risk factors for malignant change are:

  • Molar pregnancy - complete moles have 15-20% risk, partial moles have 1-5% risk
  • Patient's age ≥ 40 years or <20 years
  • Parity ≥3
  • Serum β hCG >1,00,000 IU/mL
  • Uterine size >20 weeks
  • Previous history of molar pregnancy
  • Large theca lutein cysts >6 cm in diameter

Post-evacuation uterine sonographic surveillance can be used as a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. Findings indicative of malignant transformation are:

  • Suburethral nodules
  • Myometrial nodules
  • Hypervascularity.

questions.text: A patient with a history of molar pregnancy was treated with suction and evacuation. Which method of contraception would you not recommend for her?
questions.solution:
IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) is contraindicated in this patient as the uterus is friable and can cause further bleeding. 

Accepted methods of contraception after suction evacuation in molar pregnancy include:

  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate
  • Barrier methods.

questions.text: What will be the WHO score in a patient with low-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia?
questions.solution:
Low-risk GTN has a WHO score of 0 to 6. High-risk GTN has a WHO score of ≥ 7.

Features Low risk High risk
Total score 0-6 ≥7
Age ≤39 years ≥40 years
hCG ≤105 IU/L ≥105 IU/L
Type of antecedent pregnancy Molar pregnancy Full term pregnancy
Duration of antecedent pregnancy <4 months >12 months
Metastasis site Lungs, vagina Brain, liver
Number of metastases <4  >8
Size of the tumor <3 cm >5 cm
Antecedent chemotherapy Single-agent chemotherapy Multiple-agent chemotherapy

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed to have choriocarcinoma two years post-evacuation of molar pregnancy. Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The common sites of metastases of choriocarcinoma are in the following order:

  • Lungs - most common
  • Vagina - second most common
  • Vulva
  • Kidneys
  • Liver
  • Ovaries
  • Brain
  • Bowel

Lung metastases present as cannon-ball or snowstorm appearance on chest X-ray. Vaginal metastases present as purplish sub-urethral nodules.

questions.text: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is considered as stage _____.
questions.solution:
Metastases in the lungs are considered stage III GTN (gestational trophoblastic neoplasia) in FIGO classification.

International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) staging for GTN is as follows:

Stage Description
I GTN confined to the uterus

II

GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures    

(adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
III GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
IV All other metastatic sites i.e. kidney, liver, brain, bowel, etc.

The chest X-ray below shows lung metastasis - stage III GTN. 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN: 

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma 

Treatment for low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with complaints of hemoptysis, vaginal bleeding, and abdominal pain for 7 days. Chest X-ray is shown below. Transabdominal USG revealed a solid mass occupying the uterus which was found to be choriocarcinoma with a WHO score of 8. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of high-risk (WHO) stage III choriocarcinoma which is treated with EMA-CO regimen. The given X-ray shows numerous, dense, bilateral metastatic nodules, of varying sizes indicative of lung metastases.

The components of EMA-CO are:

  • Etoposide
  • Methotrexate
  • Actinomycin D
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Oncovin i.e. vincristine
Risk Criteria Treatment
Low
  • FIGO stage I GTN
  • FIGO Stage II or III GTN with a WHO risk score <6
 Single agent chemotherapy with Methotrextate or Actinomycin D.
High
  • Stages II and III with WHO risk score >7
  • Stage IV disease

EMA-CO regimen

Option A: PSTT (placental-site trophoblastic tumor) and ETT (epithelioid trophoblastic tumors) are treated by hysterectomy only, as they are resistant to chemotherapy.

Option B: R-CHOP regimen is used for B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option D: MVAC regimen is used for advanced bladder carcinoma.

questions.text: Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from _____.
questions.solution:
Placental-site trophoblastic tumor arises from implantation site intermediate trophoblast. As syncytiotrophoblastic cells are generally absent in this site, it is composed mainly of cytotrophoblastic cells.

Patients with placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly elevated serum β-hCG levels. Local invasion into the myometrium and lymphatics occurs. Hysterectomy is the preferred treatment.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of early miscarriage presented with amenorrhoea. Her serum beta hCG levels were persistently low and USG revealed a single solid mass in the uterine fundus. Histopathological examination of the biopsy showed abundant intermediate trophoblastic cells. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placental-site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT). Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice because they are locally invasive tumors and resistant to chemotherapy.

PSTT is a rare tumor arising from intermediate trophoblastic of the placental bed. Patients with placental site trophoblastic tumors present with vaginal bleeding and modestly elevated serum β-hCG levels. They produce variant forms of hCG.
